values.Name: Mike Uslan
values.Note: Becomes writer for DC comics. Eventually producer of Batman (1989), The Dark Knight (2008), The Dark Knight Rises (2012). Designed and taught a course on comic books as an undergraduate at Indiana University. (1971). Exhibit at Lilly Library (2005). IU commencement speaker (2006). http://kwhs.wharton.upenn.edu/2011/07/the-boy-who-loved-batman-movie-producer-michael-uslans-journey-from-new-jersey-to-hollywood/

The following is a brief criticism of Avengers #79.  Jones is still active as a video and mixed-media artist. http://philipmalloryjones.com

values.Name: Larry Raybourne
values.Note: Writer identifies himself as a "Studio Card Writer" with HI BROWS. HI BROWS was an imprint of American Greetings, which produced humorous greeting cards called "studio cards." R. Crumb and perhaps other Cleveland-based illustrators worked at one time for HI BROWS.

values.Name: Tony Isabella
values.Note: Becomes writer/editor for both DC and Marvel. Creates first African-American superhero. http://tonyisabella.blogspot.com

values.Name: Roy Thomas

values.Name: Roy Thomas
values.Note: See other notes on Roy Thomas.

values.Name: Steve Gerber
values.Note: Wikipedia identifies this as the same Gerber who wrote for Marvel and DC in '70s and '80s. Creator of Howard the Duck. As a teenager associated with Roy Thomas and Jerry Balls as an early fan and creator of fanzine (St. Louis area?). Also wrote computer user books.

values.Name: Derrill Rothermich
values.Note: Student at Missouri School of Mines. Edited fanzines. See entry for Rothermich in Founders of Comic Fandom (2010): 77.

values.Name: Derill Rothermich
values.Note: see note above on Rothermich

values.Name: Bruce Long
values.Note: Letter quote in Bulletin, re: complaint about too much Marvel merchandise. Writer lists rank: PFC.

values.Name: Bruce Long
values.Note: Writer signs with rank: PFC. Complains Marvel being turned into  fad.

values.Salutation: Dear Psychedelic Stan and Jumpin  Jack
values.Name: Pressed Rat and Warthog
values.Note: The preoccupations of the late sixties are notable in this letter s salutation, closing, and signed names. The language of the era, the pop culture scene, similarly penetrates many of the letters and editors  comments.

values.Name: Donald McGregor
values.Note: Donald F. McGregor became part of the writing team at Marvel during the 70s and pioneered the graphic novel. He appears approximately six times in FF before 1970 as a writer of fan letters, all before breaking into the comics industry.

values.Name: Donald McGregor
